name: titanium tetrachloride production | titanium tetrachloride | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24538/documentation

This dataset refers to the production of 1 kg of titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4) from high-grade titanium slag in China. ;TiCl4 is normally produced from rutile and in some cases from a mix of ilmenite concentrate, rutile and high-grade slag. Due to scarcity of natural rutile resources in China, the high-grade titanium slag is considered as the principal input. The dataset is based on the publication from Gao et al (2018).;Table 2 of the Gao et al (2018) publication, provides cradle-to-gate data for the production of 1 ton of Ti sponge. For this dataset, only the data provided in the column ''chlorination and refining'' in table 2 of the abovementioned publication were taken into account here, because the chlorination and refining process is the sole process for the production of TiCl4. The amount of high-grade titanium slag, which serves as the principal input for the production of TiCl4 has been estimated.;Reference:;Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

The activity starts with the processing of titania slag that contains approximately 94% TiO2.

The activity ends with the production of titanium tetrachloride.

No allocation is applied.

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Dataset valid for the entire corresponding region. Since China is the major producer of pure titanium metal, it is assumed that China is also the major producer of titanium tetrachloride.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: During the chlorination and refining process, titania slag is mixed with petroleum coke and placed in a chlorination furnace between 1073 and 1173 K, resulting in the production of crude titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4). The crude TiCl4 is refined further with reaction of the process being: 2TiO2 + 4Cl2 + 3C -> 2TiCl4 + 2CO + CO2. Titanium tetrachloride is used for the production of the pure titanium metal (titanium sponge). The data are assumed to be valid on average for 5 years after the publication of that article.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: According to the authors of the publication used as a source for this dataset, data were collected from titanium sponge manufacturing companies in the province of Sichuan and Shaanxi through surveys, but considering at the same time average national production statistics. Therefore, the data are assumed to represent the average production of titanium metal in China.Therefore, the data are assumed to represent the average production of titanium metal in China through the Kroll process.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
The individual exchanges have been taken from the column ''chlorination and refining'' of table 2 of Gao et al. (2018).

Special attention was given to the chlorine input due to the fact that part of the chlorine is recycled from the electrolysis of magnesium chloride (MgCl2 -> Mg + Cl2), which is produced during the titanium sponge production. The rest of the chlorine is obtained from an external source, which is assumed to be brought to the site in liquid form.

The fuels (raw coal, natural gas and crude oil) have been linked with the respective ecoinvent heat production datasets (check exchange comments). Calculation of the thermal energy is also available in the respective comments. The individual emissions listed in table 2  (CO2, SO2, NOx, CO, CH4, N2O, NMVOC, As, Cd, Cr, Hg, Ni, Pb, V, Zn and Particulates) are not considered here because they represent indirect emissions from heat (from natural gas, crude oil and hard coal) and electricity production that are already modelled in the energy production datasets. Therefore, those emissions are not included in order to avoid double counting.

However, the direct carbon monoxide & dioxide emissions are included here based on the stoichiometric equations of the chlorination and refining process (more information on exchange comment section of each emission), as these are direct process emissions. Non-carbon emissions from the burning of petroleum coke have not been taken into consideration, therefore the  emission profile resulting from the burning of coke is not fully included.

The high-grade titanium slag used as the primary input was assumed to contain 94% TiO2 (data on the high-grade slag come from the same region as used in the Gao et al publication (Liao et al. 2021). Its amount is calculated based on the stoichiometric equation: 2TiO2 + 4Cl2 + 3C -> 2TiCl4 + 2CO + CO2 (for more info consult the respective exchange comment).

Finally, the spent alkali liquor produced as a byproduct according to Gao et al (2018) has been approximated as blast furnace slag. This approximation is based on the work of Xiong et al (2010),  that describes the production of TiCl4 from titanium slag in the Panzhihua city (as in the publication from Gao et al 2018), where the main output from the carbochlorination process seems to be furnace slag (Xiong et al. 2010).


References:
Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.

Liao, W., Heijungs, R., & Huppes, G. (2012). Thermodynamic resource indicators in LCA: a case study on the titania produced in Panzhihua city, southwest China. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 17(8), 951-961. doi:10.1007/s11367-012-0429-4

Xiong, S.-f., Yuan, Z.-f., Xu, C., & Xi, L. (2010). Composition of off-gas produced by combined fluidized bed chlorination for preparation of TiCl4. Transactions of Nonferrous Metals Society of China, 20(1), 128-134. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/S1003-6326(09)60109-6

exchanges.description:
The stoichiometric amount of Cl2 is based on the following equations: 

i) 2TiO2 + 4Cl2 + 3C -> 2TiCl4 + 2CO + CO2. This is the chlorination and refining process, where approximately 0.7476 kg of Cl2 are required as an input for the production of 1 kg of TiCl4)

ii) TiCl4 + 2Mg -> Ti + 2MgCl2. This is the reduction and distillation process. This means that for the production of 1 kg of Ti sponge, 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 are required as input, meaning that 2.9626 kg of Cl2 are needed as input for the production of 1 kg of Ti sponge.

However, in the Kroll process for titanium sponge production, approximately 45.3% of the chlorine is recovered through the electrolysis of magnesium chloride (MgCl2 -> Mg + Cl2) and reused as input to the chlorination and refining process, meaning that only 54.7% of the stoichiometric input needs to be supplied externally (1620 kg required as reported in Table 2 in Gao et al. (2018), compared to 2962.6 kg needed as input for the production of 1 metric ton of Ti sponge).

In the end, the chlorine input was adjusted to represent the production of 1 kg of TiCl4 (first by dividing by 1000 and by dividing again by 3.9626).

Finally, the liquid chlorine is assumed as input instead of gaseous, since the it is usually transported in liquid form which requires compression that is not considered in the gaseous chlorine exchange. As a result, it is assumed that liquid chlorine is transformed to the required gaseous form onsite. 

Reference:
Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240).

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of heat produced from the combustion of hard coal (3530 kg) and crude oil (851 kg) in the chlorination and refining process for the production of 1 metric ton of titanium sponge. 

These values were taken from Gao et al. (2018) and were adjusted to represent the production of 1 kg of TiCl4  (first by dividing by 1000 and by dividing again by 3.9626),  based on the fact that for the production of 1 kg of Ti sponge, 3.9626 kg of TiCl4 are needed based on the following reaction: TiCl4 + 2Mg ->Ti + 2MgCl2. For more information about this equation, refer to the titanium sponge production dataset.

Therefore the amounts of hard coal and crude oil required per 1 kg of TiCl4 are 0.890823497 kg and 0.214756599 kg respectively.

The thermal energy from each source is calculated by multiplying the gross calorific value of each fuel (45.8 MJ/kg for crude oil and 30.4 MJ/kg for hard coal according toTable 5.1, chapter 5.6.3, page 35 of the data quality guidelines of Ecoinvent version 3) with the amount of each fuel as mentioned above. The thermal energies from each source are summed to obtain the reported value.

Reference:
Gao, F., Nie, Z., Yang, D., Sun, B., Liu, Y., Gong, X., & Wang, Z. (2018). Environmental impacts analysis of titanium sponge production using Kroll process in China. Journal of Cleaner Production, 174, 771-779. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2017.09.240.
